Hi All,

Apologies for cross-posting to junit and prevayler, but I am working on 
an intersection of the two - I think you'll find my post relevant to 
both lists.

Anyways, a testing issue that has been bothering me for a while is the 
issue of testing persistent storage.

Recently I have been using prevayler ( http://www.prevayler.org ) in 
place of an RDBMS, and have been writing unit tests in JUnit ( 
http://www.junit.org ).

The point is, for a system like prevayler, in order to really confirm 
whether something has been persisted or not, you need to shut down the 
JVM, and then re-start and then check whether the object you persisted 
still exists.

Implementing this in JUnit seems slightly problematic.  My current 
thinking is that maybe some kind of ant task that spawned a new JVM 
would help.  Thinking some more, I guess the test class would need to be 
accessing the Prevayler system via a socket (like an RDBMS) and tell it 
to shut down and then restart inbetween requesting the persistence of an 
object, and checking the object has been persisted.

Of course this sort of defeats the purpose of the prevayler which is to 
have all your persistence in the same JVM as your processes - I guess 
you could delete everything and call the prevayler initialize methods, 
but this suffers from the problem that the test is not actually testing 
the thing we want, i.e. a shutdown and restart of the JVM, because if 
the persistence doesn't survive this event, then it's of no use.

I guess one could have a separately stored list of persisted objects, 
say in a text file, that the junit test would record its persistence 
attempts to, and this could be used on startup to confirm what should be 
in the prevayler persistent store.  hmmm.

Any thoughts or comments greatly appreciated.

CHEERS> SAM
